content.question: Read the question carefully. You can receive full credit only by directly answering all aspects of the question. You must answer the question in essay form. An outline or bulleted list is not acceptable. (Note: This exam uses the chronological designations B.C.E. (before the common era) and C.E. (common era). These designations correspond to B.C. (before Christ) and A.D. (anno Domini), which are used in some art history resources.) The work shown is the Arnolfini Portrait, painted by Jan van Eyck c. 1434 C.E. The painting has been interpreted as communicating cultural attitudes about marriage and relationships. Select and completely identify another painting, drawing, or print that communicates cultural attitudes about marriage and relationships. You may select a work from the list below or any other relevant painting, drawing, or print from Early Europe and Colonial Americas (200–1750 C.E.). Describe the imagery of both the Arnolfini Portrait and your selected work. Using specific visual evidence from both works, explain at least one similarity and at least one difference in how the imagery of the two works depicts marriage and relationships. Explain at least one difference in the cultural attitudes communicated by the two works about marriage and relationships. Use specific contextual evidence about both the Arnolfini Portrait and your selected work in the explanation. When identifying the work you select, you should try to include all of the following identifiers: title or designation, name of the artist and/or culture of origin, date of creation, and materials. You will earn credit for the identification if you provide at least two accurate identifiers, but you will not be penalized if any additional identifiers you provide are inaccurate. If you select a work from the list below, you must include at least two accurate identifiers beyond those that are given. Henri IV Receives the Portrait of Marie de’ Medici Spaniard and Indian Produce a Mestizo The Tête à Tête

unit.text: 3: Early Europe and Colonial Americas, 200 - 1750 CE

topic.text: 3.1: Cultural Contexts of Early European and Colonial American Art

skill.text: Skill 1.A: Identify a work of art (or group of related works of art), providing-  a. title or designation.  b. name of artist.  c. culture of origin.  d. style.  e. date of creation.  f. materials.
